results.title: Coals Coals (Horses and Carts)
results.creator_credit: David Pitt, Francis Gysin and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: The last of the horse-drawn delivery drays of Charringtons. The film is a nostalgic record of the work of the horses and delivery men. There is no glamour, the stables are scruffy, the men dirty, but the horses are immaculate. The title comes from a music-hall song which provides the background music.

results.title: Coal valley
results.creator_credit: Conon Fraser, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Presents the case for small scale private mining by examining the independence, ingenuity and engineering skill of the men who built and work five small privately owned coal mines on the west coast of New Zealand’s South Island. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Coal from Westland
results.brief_description: Coal mining in the forest mountain of Westland, New Zealand. Shows miners at work in coal pits, at home with their families and enjoying leisure hours. The camera explores the rugged beauty of the mountains and deep gorges surrounding the mines.

results.title: Coaches
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Coaches is about four people preparing their teams for the Pre-Olympics. Their distinctive approaches emerge during the fights, the good times, and those critical post-game sessions when feelings are raw or jubilant. It is a film about human growth.

results.title: Clunies Ross: a man of science
results.brief_description: The life, work and interests of Sir Ian Clunies Ross. Some of the rapid advances made in the 1940’s and 1950’s as a result of industrial and scientific research during his chairmanship. His many interests include the establishment of the Wool Research Foundation and also the Tropical Division of the CSIRO; artificial rainmaking; pasture improvement; science research applied to primary and secondary industry; improved status of universities and the building of International House at the University of Melbourne. His Memorial will be a National Science Centre in Melbourne. Narrated by Eric Pearce.

results.title: The Clown princes of Hollywood. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell, Gregstan Productions and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Explains that some of the early comedians like Charlie Chaplin and Harold Lloyd became Hollywood royalty, while others who made audiences laugh but never reached the top of the ladder were dubbed “clown princes”. Uses original silent footage to examine the different styles and personalities of some of the comedians, including Charlie Chaplin, Harold Lloyd, Larry Seman, Charlie Chase, Laurel and Hardy, Ben Turpin and Billy West.

results.title: Clouds above. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Presents the more common types of clouds, and explains in detail the processes of evaporation and condensation. An animated sequence demonstrates how the sun, air and water working together cause water vapour to rise and how subsequent condensation causes clouds to form. Traces the complete water cycle. Shows the importance of clouds to humans, particularly in farming, fishing and aviation.

results.title: Cloud over the coral reef
results.creator_credit: Lee Tepley, R.E. Johannes and Moonlight Productions
results.brief_description: This film considers the effect of sewage pollution and sedimentation on the coral reefs of the tropics and also examines a severe ecological disturbance of unknown origin - the population explosion of the coral eating Crown of Thorns starfish, which may be caused by pollution or some other form of man’s activity.

results.title: Cloud over Ohio
results.creator_credit: Edward Plumb, Karl Maslowski and S O H I O
results.brief_description: In spite of a high annual rainfall, the state of Ohio, USA has faced severe droughts. This film illustrates the part played by water in the daily lives of the inhabitants, also its use in industry and agriculture, then probes for reasons behind the apparent wastage of water resources. Draws particular attention to wastage of both soil and water resulting from soil erosion. Includes close-up shots of rain drops striking unprotected soil, showing the extent and nature of the damage caused.
